results.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''A Political Babe'' (Op-Ed, May 1): Like Pat Schroeder, I, too, tired of questions about my hair and clothes when I was on the campaign trail.
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Political Babe'' (Op-Ed, May 1): Like Pat Schroeder, I, too, tired of questions about my hair and clothes when I was on the campaign trail.

results.abstract: International Space Station is brushing against wisps of atmosphere and dropping 1.5 to 2 miles a week as it orbits Earth at height of 210 miles; one of space shuttle Atlantis's missions will be to nudge space station upward by 20 to 25 miles to be ready for next piece of station, Zvezda service module, which Russia has scheduled for launching in July; photos (M)

headline.main: As the Space Station Falls, NASA Moves to Prop It Up

results.snippet: The space station is falling. As it orbits Earth, even at a height of 210 miles, the nascent International Space Station brushes against wisps of atmosphere, causing it gradually to lose speed and altitude.    The Sun, as it approaches the height of...
results.lead_paragraph: The space station is falling. As it orbits Earth, even at a height of 210 miles, the nascent International Space Station brushes against wisps of atmosphere, causing it gradually to lose speed and altitude. The Sun, as it approaches the height of its 11-year sunspot cycle, churns in a more unruly roil, throwing out more high-energy radiation that puffs out Earth's outer atmosphere. And the station falls faster.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students explore the future of 'orbital vacations' and create fanciful tours of the Milky Way Galaxy.
results.snippet: In this lesson, students explore the future of 'orbital vacations' and create fanciful tours of the Milky Way Galaxy.

results.abstract: David B Guralnik, lexicographer, dies at age 79; photo (M)
results.snippet: David B. Guralnik, a lexicographer whose definitions of the American language guided tens of millions of people who thumbed through the dictionaries he edited, died on Friday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He was 79.    He had colon cancer, his...
results.lead_paragraph: David B. Guralnik, a lexicographer whose definitions of the American language guided tens of millions of people who thumbed through the dictionaries he edited, died on Friday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He was 79. He had colon cancer, his daughter, Eve Harrington, said.

results.abstract: Astronauts from shuttle Atlantis complete several tasks in their maintenance mission to International Space Station (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Eagerly Begin Space Station's Repairs

results.snippet: Spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis made short work of a wobbly crane, a broken antenna and a half-finished construction boom today, marking a successful first day of maintenance work on the International Space Station.     Working...
results.lead_paragraph: Spacewalking astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis made short work of a wobbly crane, a broken antenna and a half-finished construction boom today, marking a successful first day of maintenance work on the International Space Station. Working quickly, the astronauts Jeffrey N. Williams and Lt. Col. James S. Voss were able to add a few extra tasks to their agenda, wrapping up their work in 6 hours 44 minutes.

results.abstract: Mir space station remains in orbit, largely because it is a source of great national pride in Russia; Russia's continuing investment in MIR irks NASA because inadequate financing has prevented Russians from completing critical components of nascent International Space Station, which is now more than two years behind schedule; Mir is operating because of last-minute money from Western investors; photos (L)
results.snippet: By some plans, it should have been long dead. With most of its structure disintegrated by a fiery re-entry through Earth's atmosphere, the remains of the giant spacecraft should be resting on the bottom of the Pacific Ocean.    Instead, the Russian...
results.lead_paragraph: By some plans, it should have been long dead. With most of its structure disintegrated by a fiery re-entry through Earth's atmosphere, the remains of the giant spacecraft should be resting on the bottom of the Pacific Ocean. Instead, the Russian Mir space station remains in orbit. Even as astronauts from the space shuttle Atlantis were preparing the nascent International Space Station for future occupancy, a pair of astronauts aboard Mir were busily repairing worn components and readying it for future visits. Previously abandoned, battered and showing all the effects of its sometimes troubled 14 years in space, the Mir just keeps going on and on.

results.abstract: Brazil and other nations in satellite launching business are hoping boom in telecommunications satellites will boost their spaceports; Brazil's Alcantara launching center's site near Equator, where Earth's rotation speed is greatest, allows rockets launched from there to carry relatively heavy payloads and use less fuel; map; tables of launches from various sites; photos (M)

headline.main: A Developing Nation on the Frontiers of Space

results.snippet: In the satellite launching business, as in real estate, location is everything. Because of that simple fact, the spaceport the Brazilian government has built here on the eastern edge of the Amazon basin, and is now making available to foreign...
results.lead_paragraph: In the satellite launching business, as in real estate, location is everything. Because of that simple fact, the spaceport the Brazilian government has built here on the eastern edge of the Amazon basin, and is now making available to foreign companies and governments, may soon become a very valuable piece of property. Situated 2 degrees south of the Equator, the Alcantara launching center, built by the Brazilian military two decades ago, has become the focal point of what is perhaps the most ambitious unmanned space program in any developing country. But it is the boom in telecommunications satellites that is likely to ensure it a prosperous future.

results.abstract: Yevgeny Vasilevich Khrunov, early Russian astronaut, dies at age of 67 (S)
results.snippet: Yevgeny Vasilevich Khrunov, an early Russian astronaut who took part in the first linkup of two manned spacecraft high above the earth, has died at the age of 67. In reporting his death from Moscow on Tuesday, the news agency Itar-Tass said that...
results.lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Vasilevich Khrunov, an early Russian astronaut who took part in the first linkup of two manned spacecraft high above the earth, has died at the age of 67. In reporting his death from Moscow on Tuesday, the news agency Itar-Tass said that several of his fellow astronauts had gathered on the day of his death to mourn him. The date, place and cause of death were not given.

results.abstract: Article on South Orange-Maplewood School District in New Jersey, where elementary education director Marilyn Davenport, is applying theory of multiple intelligences developed by Harvard University Prof Howard Gardner; district's fourth graders scored higher in math, language arts and sciences than statewide average in 1999 Elementary School Proficiency Assessment tests; photo

headline.main: A School District Under a Microscope

results.snippet: ''It's like astronaut camp for teachers.''    In any word association game, that would hardly be the way most residents here would think of their school district.

results.abstract: Nation's 172 veterans hospitals hire NASA to set up system where errors can be reported without fear of penalty and information used to make everyone safer; 1999 report by Institute of Medicine concluded that medical mistakes kill 44,000 to 98,000 Americans annually (M)

headline.main: V.A. Plans No-Penalty Medical Error Reporting

results.snippet: In a groundbreaking program, the nation's 172 veterans hospitals hired NASA today to do for medical safety what it does for aviation safety: set up a system where errors can be reported without fear of penalty and use the information to make everyone...
results.lead_paragraph: In a groundbreaking program, the nation's 172 veterans hospitals hired NASA today to do for medical safety what it does for aviation safety: set up a system where errors can be reported without fear of penalty and use the information to make everyone safer. A report by the Institute of Medicine concluded last year that medical mistakes killed 44,000 to 98,000 hospitalized Americans a year.

results.abstract: Princeton University holds commencement exercise; university president Dr Harold T Shapiro speaks; Cornell University holds commencement; Sen Charles E Schumer speaks (M)

headline.main: Commencements; Remember Ethics, Graduates Are Told

results.snippet: Princeton University's president warned graduates today that crumbling respect for authorities and institutions meant that a sense of moral purpose must temper their use of technological and scientific advances like genetic research.    ''We have to...
results.lead_paragraph: Princeton University's president warned graduates today that crumbling respect for authorities and institutions meant that a sense of moral purpose must temper their use of technological and scientific advances like genetic research. ''We have to accept the fact that in a world that is changing as fast as ours, all thoughtful citizens will have to share in the anguish of finding the right moral perspective within which to accommodate these changes,'' said the university president, Dr. Harold T. Shapiro, who is the chairman of the National Bioethics Advisory Commission.
